newsitem.title: USA: Vantive Corp drops on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Vantive Corp drops on profit-taking.

text.p: Shares of software maker Vantive Corp fell more than eight percent on Nasdaq on Tuesday morning due to profit-taking, analysts said.
Shares of the Santa Clara, Calif.-based firm fell 5-1/4 to 59-1/2 in light trade.
"It's a stock that has been very much on an upswing lately," said James Pickrel, an analyst at research firm Hambrecht & Quist.
He said of the stock's decline, "Given their run-up on fairly thin trading volume, I think it's just a couple of people doing a little profit-taking."
Eric Upin, an analyst at Robertson Stephens, cited some insider selling by management and comments in the September 30 issue of Barron's that the stock may be overvalued.
"It's frankly a difficult company to value ... there is a lot of difficulty in establishing what the long-term growth rate for the company is," Upin said.
"Almost anyone that owns the stock, even if they bought in August, are up substantially, so there is a lot of profit," he added.
Vantive's stock price has risen steadily from 25-1/2 on July 16 to 64-3/4 yesterday.
Company officials were not available for comment.
Pickrel said that despite today's sell-off, the company's fundamentals remain strong.
"The company has been on a very strong product and market cycle, so the fundamentals and the performance of the stock have been very strong," he said.
Vantive operates in the rapidly growing new area of customer interaction software, which allows clients to communicate more effectively with a customer support group.
